answers.author: Justine Bruno
answers.text:
Defined Benefit - A pension plan under which an employee receives a set monthly amount upon retirement, guaranteed for their life or the joint lives of the member and their spouse. This benefit may also include a cost-of-living increase 
each year during retirement. The monthly benefit amount is based upon the participant’s wages and length of service. Employees typically don't pay any of their earnings to participate in a defined benefit plan - their employer does.  
Defined benefit plans are more costly for employers than defined contribution plans, which is why they are being phased out.
Defined Contribution - A retirement savings program under which an employer promises certain contributions to a participant’s account during employment, but with no guaranteed retirement benefit. The ultimate benefit is based exclusively upon the contributions to, and investment earnings of the plan. The benefit ceases when the account balance is depleted, regardless of the retiree’s age or 
circumstances. Employees put their own money into a defined contribution plan, like a 401(k) or a 403(b).
